summary:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this document about New Covent Garden Market in 3-5 sentences. Let me start by reading through the content carefully.

The main topic is the New Covent Garden Market in London. It's the largest wholesale market for fruits, vegetables, and flowers in the UK. The document mentions its location in Nine Elms, size, number of companies, and its role in supplying London's restaurants, schools, etc. Then there's info about the Flower Market and operating hours. 

Next, the history section talks about how it moved from Covent Garden to Nine Elms in the 70s, the CGMA's role, and how it adapted when supermarkets grew. Then there's the redevelopment part, Project Chrysalis, the £2 billion plan with Vinci and St. Modwen, and the impact on jobs and housing. The construction timeline includes delays, issues with the new units leading to a lawsuit, and ongoing phases until 2026.

Key concepts: size, role in supplying London, history of relocation, redevelopment projects, challenges during redevelopment, and the ongoing phases. I need to highlight the main points without getting too detailed. Make sure to mention the market's significance, its history, the redevelopment efforts, and the challenges faced. Keep it concise, 3-5 sentences. Avoid specific dates unless necessary. Focus on the main topic and key concepts.
</think>

New Covent Garden Market in London is the UK's largest wholesale fruit, vegetable, and flower market, serving 40% of London's out-of-home food demand and supplying businesses like restaurants and hospitals. Originally established in 1974 after relocating from Covent Garden, it has adapted to industry changes, shifting focus to the hospitality sector amid supermarket growth. A major redevelopment project, Project Chrysalis, aims to modernize the site with new housing, commercial spaces, and infrastructure, though it faced delays and disputes over facility quality. The market remains a critical hub for traders and a symbol of London's evolving urban regeneration.

qa_pairs.chunk:
Chunk:

[S1] New Covent Garden Market


# New Covent Garden Market



**New Covent Garden Market** in Nine Elms, London, is the largest wholesale fruit, vegetable and flower market in the United Kingdom. [S2] It covers a site of 57 acres (23 ha) and is home to about 200 fruit, vegetable and flower companies. [S3] The market serves 40% of the fruit and vegetables eaten outside of the home in London, and provides ingredients to many of London's restaurants, hotels, schools, prisons, hospitals and catering businesses. [S4] The Flower Market, which offers flowers, plants, foliages, sundries and interior decorations from the UK and from around the globe, is visited by 75% of florists in London, many of whom place morning orders and return to restock during the day. [S5] The Flower Market wholesalers are open from 04:00 to 10:00 Monday to Saturday and the Fruit & Vegetable Market wholesalers trade from around 00:00 – 06:00 Monday to Saturday. [S6] There is a £5 entry fee for visitors driving to the market. [S7] The nearest London Underground stations are Battersea Power Station and Nine Elms, both opened in 2021 as part of the Northern line extension to Battersea. [S8] ## History

For many years the capital's main wholesale market for fruit and vegetables was at Covent Garden in central London, just as the meat market was at Smithfield, fish at Billingsgate and other food at Leadenhall Market. [S9] As the supply of fresh food was considered strategically important, the Covent Garden Market Authority (CGMA) was set up in 1961, charged with modernising and overseeing the administration of the produce market. [S10] Construction began in 1971 south of the Thames in Battersea, on the site of the former Nine Elms Locomotive Works and Nine Elms railway station and Nine Elms loco shed, which closed on 9 July 1967 at the end of steam on the SR. [S11] The new market opened for business on 11 November 1974, although its ceremonial opening, by the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh, was on 26 June 1975. [S12] The CGMA is a statutory corporation, which reports to the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA). [S13] As a statutory corporation, the UK treasury has shielded New Covent Garden from changes in conditions of the wholesale industry. [S14] In the 1980s, when the wholesale industry was threatened by the growth of supermarkets, New Covent Garden Market were able to switch focus to the hospitality industry. [S15] Since 1990, successive governments have attempted to privatise or dispose of the market as a going concern. [S16] ## Redevelopment

By 2005, the buildings were beginning to show signs of their age, in need of modernising. [S17] Following a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers, the CGMA and DEFRA agreed on a plan (known as Project Chrysalis) to reform and redevelop the market to enable it to be eventually sold. [S18] The CGMA, which had previously paid any profits as dividends to HM Treasury, was allowed to retain its profits to fund the initial planning work. [S19] The CGMA signed a contract with Vinci and St. [S20] Modwen in 2013 for the market's regeneration for a five-year development project Funded by releasing spare land to the developers to build residential properties, the £2 billion project is expected to provide 2000 additional jobs, include 3000 new homes, 135,000 square feet of commercial units and 100,000 square feet of retail facilities. [S21] The project is a part of the wider Nine Elms Regeneration area, which also encompasses the relocation of the Embassy of the United States, London to Nine Elms, the regeneration of Battersea Power Station, and an extension of the Underground's Northern line (funded in part by the CGMA). [S22] ## Construction timeline

By the time redevelopment works started in 2015 (months behind schedule), the project's timeline had increased in scope and was expected to take 10 years. [S23] The Flower Market, situated near the Battersea Park Road entrance, opened in April 2017, with the Food Exchange opening in January 2018. [S24] Phase One of the regeneration completed in December 2019.
qa_pairs.question: How large is the site of New Covent Garden Market?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The site of New Covent Garden Market covers 57 acres (23 ha).<cite>[S2]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.thinking:
Okay, the user is asking how large the site of New Covent Garden Market is. Let me check the supporting context provided.

Looking through the sentences, [S2] mentions that the market covers a site of 57 acres (23 ha). That seems to directly answer the question. I should make sure there's no other sentence with different information. Scanning through the rest, [S1] just mentions the name, [S3] talks about the number of companies, [S4] and others discuss the market's services and hours. No other size details are given. So the answer is 57 acres, cited from [S2]. The user might need the citation, so I'll format it correctly.

qa_pairs.chunk:
Chunk:

[S1] ## Construction timeline

By the time redevelopment works started in 2015 (months behind schedule), the project's timeline had increased in scope and was expected to take 10 years. [S2] The Flower Market, situated near the Battersea Park Road entrance, opened in April 2017, with the Food Exchange opening in January 2018. [S3] Phase One of the regeneration completed in December 2019. [S4] However, traders were unimpressed about the quality of the new units, relating to logistics, spacing and electric capacity. [S5] In 2018, their Tenant association sued the CGMA over breach of contract.
